etymologies: Middle English (as a verb): probably a variant of shatter

examples.text: scatter the coconut over the icing
his family are hoping to scatter his ashes at sea

definitions: cover (a surface) with objects thrown or spread randomly over it

examples.text: the sandy beaches are scattered with driftwood

shortDefinitions: cover surface with objects thrown or spread randomly over it

definitions: occur or be found at intervals rather than all together

examples.text: there are many mills scattered throughout the marshlands

shortDefinitions: occur or be found at intervals rather than all together

definitions: (of a group of people or animals) separate and move off quickly in different directions

examples.text: the roar made the dogs scatter

shortDefinitions: separate and move off quickly in different directions

definitions: cause (a group of people or animals) to move off quickly in different directions

examples.text: he charged across the foyer, scattering people

shortDefinitions: cause group of people or animals to move off quickly in different directions

definitions: deflect or diffuse (electromagnetic radiation or particles)

examples.text: the light is scattered as it strikes particles suspended in the air

definitions: (of a pitcher) allow (several hits) at intervals so as to result in little or no scoring

examples.text: Fernandez struck out 14 while scattering three hits over eight scoreless innings

shortDefinitions: allow hits at intervals with little or no scoring

definitions: a small, dispersed amount of something

examples.text: a scatter of houses on the north shore

definitions: the degree to which repeated measurements or observations of a quantity differ.
shortDefinitions: degree to which repeated measurements or observations of quantity differ

definitions: the scattering of light, other electromagnetic radiation, or particles.
shortDefinitions: scattering of light, other electromagnetic radiation
